docs.lead_paragraph: It is disturbing that so many members of Congress were willing to repeat a biotechnology company’s talking points in the Congressional Record.

docs.lead_paragraph: Implants are the best solution to replace lost teeth in most cases, and they are more economical than bridges over time.

headline.print_headline: A Dental Shift: Implants Instead of Bridges

docs.lead_paragraph: If I have one serious regret about my age, it is that my permanent teeth developed before New York, my hometown, got fluoridated water. I first lost a permanent molar to decay in my early 20s, and the resulting bridge has had to be replaced several times in subsequent decades, ultimately as a four-part apparatus. Now that has to go as well. Because I could not floss and clean properly under the bridge and between the supporting crowns, I developed a severe periodontal infection.

headline.main: A Dental Shift: Implants Instead of Bridges

docs.snippet: Implants are the best solution to replace lost teeth in most cases, and they are more economical than bridges over time.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, met on Monday night with a group of liberal Senate Democrats who urged him not to back down from his decision to put a government-run insurance plan, or public option, in the major health care legislation he is working to finalize. Mr. Reid has said he would include a public plan in the bill with a provision for states to opt out if they do not want to offer it. But Mr. Reid is still short at least 3 of the 60 votes he needs on a motion to bring the health care bill up for debate.

headline.main: Senate Leader Is Urged To Push a Public Plan

docs.abstract: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid is urged by liberal Senate Democrats not to back down from his decision to put government-run insurance plan, or public option, in health care legislation he is working to finalize; Reid is still short at least 3 of 60 votes needed to bring bill up for debate (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The setting for a new television commercial by supporters of abortion rights is an unexpected one: a comedy club. Cory Kahaney, a comedian who appeared on ''Last Comic Standing,'' tells the audience about two patients who are told that their insurance will cover a breast reduction and a nose job. But when a third patient asks if insurance will cover an abortion -- she is 11 weeks pregnant and has discovered that part of her child's brain and skull are missing -- she is told no.
docs.abstract: Center for Reproductive Rights runs advertisement on cable stations in Washington urging Senate to exclude anti-abortion measure approved by House under health care overhaul (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the White House blog, Nancy-Ann DeParle, the director of the Office of Health Reform, rebuts recent claims by the insurance industry that the proposed health care overhaul would actually increase the cost of premiums. ''Despite being roundly and thoroughly debunked,'' she wrote, ''the industry lobby continues to release these studies and push their bogus conclusion about cost increases.''
docs.abstract: Office of Health Reform Dir Nancy-Ann DeParle uses White House blog to rebut insurance industry claims that proposed health care overhaul will increase cost of premiums; says industry is making bogus claims because legislation will likely cut their profits; photo (S)
